course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Structural Elucidation in Organic Chemistry
course.description: Use of modern ID- and 2D-NMR, IR, and Mass Spectrometric techniques for structure determination of organic molecules; theory of each technique with emphasis on development of problem-solving techniques.

reviews.author: helloworld
reviews.title: 玄學進階
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm前: IR, MS
Midterm後: NMR (1H, 13C, 2D)

呢個course主要係教用各式spectroscopic data推斷返compound既structure, i.e. DSE electives同org chem2進階版, 主要都係教下各種spectroscopy既原理同種類(同an chem 2一鬼樣)，仲有點樣睇trum，但難度比起以前d course d trum上升唔止一個級數(e.g. how to tell cis/trans or o-/m-/p- benzene from IR, how to explain all fragmentation from EI mass spec, how to use 2D nmr to solve structure, etc.

Content is more closely related to 2110 than 3120 imo, and 3d sense is quite important for this course, useful for all synthetic chemists (esp the first 2/3) even though the latter half is largely inclined towards organic chemistry (seriously, if a chemist has hours to spend on obtaining different 2D nmr spectra and analysing them why don't just obtain a fucking XRD instead?)
reviews.comment_teaching:
better than org chem 1, but notes are still a bit messy, much content mentioned during lectures is not in the notes
成日都遲up notes，臨考final前兩日先post update版notes而final 係一早講明open book，真係唔怕下世做樹咩
reviews.comment_grading:
close book midterm 40%
open book final 60%
rare 4000 level course without presentation

midterm d題目都算正路，mc問下原理同concept，睇trum有d compound叫你assign peak, explain fragmentation，有d就叫你propose structure咁

final都係mc+ interpretation 180分入面有120都叫正路，淨低60分真係玄學，比一堆核突都爆炸既trum你叫你畫返d natural product既structure，但1H nmr又數唔齊proton，d 圖又低清到每一刻你都懷疑緊自己睇緊既係墨屎定peak，1H同2d nmr d peak又唔同位，咁好咩

grade幾好，據佢講一半A range一半B range
reviews.comment_workload: only exams，midterm同final前都有exercise，final果份exercise識做既話頭120分應該冇問題，淨低就...haha

reviews.author: UB0000
reviews.title: May be good grade, but still challenging to get the best grade
reviews.comment_content:
A more in-depth study on the spectrometry from IR to MS to NMR compared to CHEM3120. In fact, it is fine if you have no background in reading those spectrums since he started teaching from 0. However, you cannot survive the course if you cannot survive the spectrum in CHEM3120.

The main focus of the course is undoubtedly NMR. Compared to CHEM3120, we try to study how we can use coupling constant more skillfully and have a taste on 2D-NMR. We also study the factors affect chemical shifts. These are all useful technique especially for synthetic chemist.

Since our midterm exam change to presentation, we don't really need to understand IR and MS deeply. In final exams, I think CHEM3120-level IR and MS is enough this year.

The detailed topics remain same as other years.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think he tries to teach in this course, and he is open to students' questions, but still, he is not providing me the best learning experience.

One main complaint from me is he tried to tell us how the NMR works (from the typical NMR to DEPT to 2D), but I could not understand anything. While he did not include these theories in exam as I have expected, he should really try to go through more example with us instead, says solving a textbook problem in class.

Fortunately, I find UCI open courseware provide their course recording on these topics (CHEM203) for free, and the Professor, James Nowick, and his TA go through some insightful examples in their discussion session. You may have a look. (Although I think it is a PG course, and they cover more than CHEM4110)
reviews.comment_grading:
In this semester, Prof Tong change midterm exams into presentation on a set of IR+ MS spectrum selected by students themselves. Since only few minutes of present is required, the workload for the midterm assignment is smaller than that in a typical midterm exam. The problem is probably that we have no clear idea what he wants to listen.

For final exam, I personally find it disastrous. The MCs are easy, and the 2D NMR questions (1 only ask about INADEQUATE, 1 with 1D 1H, 13C, DEPT, COSY, HMQC) is at an acceptable difficulty.  

But he also set some questions that he gives us the reaction, and we need to propose the products based on spectrums. Unfortunately, he doesn't give expansion for 1H NMR, so I have no idea what really the coupling patterns are. When I try to look at the value of chemical shifts instead, I cannot distinguish which is which as there are too many peaks in a small area. For 13C NMR, he did not provide DEPT, but he wants us to assign the signal to the carbon. These 4 questions drove me crazy.

Here are the statistics from Canvas:

Midterm assignment (Presentation; out of 70)
Mean: 60    Median: 60 High: 70
Upper Quartile: 65 Low: 40
Lower Quartile: 55
Me: 65

Final exam (out of 130)
Mean: 70.9   Median: 63.5 High: 101
Upper Quartile: 97.5 Low: 30
Lower Quartile: 48.5
Me: 99

My final grade: A
While it is still reasonable to get an A based on my score relative to UQ, the class only consists of 15 students this year from class quota, and 15/4=3.75. This probably mean getting the best grade remains challenging. On the other hand, my friend claim he just scored around mean last year and got A-, so you can consider it as a good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload: In fact, there is only midterm presentation and final, so the workload only comes from your desire to practice more for the exams. Furthermore, you may just spend few hours for preparing midterm presentation, and you are basically not required to memorize anything. However, you probably want to do lots of practices if you want to perform well.

reviews.author: LukaModric
reviews.title: Useful for PG or UG who would like to study PG
reviews.comment_content:
Weeks 1-2 Infrared Spectrometry
Principles, Factors affecting frequency
Intensity, frequency
Isomers
Functional groups

Week 3 Uv-Vis Spectrometry (Not covered in Mid, final)
Not mentioned

Weeks 4-5 Mass Spectroscopy
Principles
EI, CI, DI, ESI
Thirteen Rule
Hydrogen Deficiency
Nitrogen Rule
Isotope Ratio
Cleavage Mechanism
Functional Group Fragmentation

Weeks 5-8 NMR, Basic
Principles

Midterm: Mar 21st

Week 9-10 H, C-NMR
1H-NMR:
Chemical shift and factors
Spin-spin coupling and coupling constant
Magnetic inequivalence
Common coupling patterns
Types of coupling and Factors affecting coupling
More topics on 1H-NMR
13C-NMR:
Principles
Chemical shifts

Week 11-13 Advanced NMR
APT
DEPT
2D-NMR:
COSY
COSY-LR
TOCSY
NOESY
2D INADEQUATE
HETCOR
HSQC
HMQC
COLOC
HMBC
Analytical strategies

Final Exam 17 May

Relations with other CHEM courses:
CHEM 2110: ring conformations
CHEM 3120: IR, MS, NMR, keto-enol
reviews.comment_teaching:
Like CHEM 2110, the way Prof. Tong present is a little boring. But the lectures are useful as it is somehow hard to understand the lecture notes. Prof. Tong will also talk about some examples in the lectures. There are some practice questions in the lecture notes. It is better now as Prof. Tong will upload the updated notes before or after the lectures.

Sample midterm, IR&MS practice will be uploaded before the midterm.
NMR and 2D-NMR practice in separate will be uploaded before the final.
However, no answers will be uploaded.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good. Prof. Tong will aim to give half A-range and half B-range.

Final 60%

reviews.comment_workload:
Midterm: closed-book
Final: opened-book

Quite light since open book for final and not much things to be remembered in midterm and what the exams test is your analytical skills.

For the last part of final exam, it really is philosophy. The dots are overlapping.

Exam format:
Midterm: 1 hr 20 mins in class (Prof. Tong tries to extend the time like before the class and after the class)
e.g. 13:30-14:50->13:20-15:00
Final: 3 hrs->3hrs 20mins (Again Prof. Tong extended 20mins)
~10 MC for concepts
~5 interpretation of spectrum and/or propose a structure
